title: Reframing our relationship with death
content: BJ Miller is a hospice and palliative care specialist on a quest to reframe our relationship with death. In this episode, BJ begins with how his own brush with death radically shifted his perspective and ultimately forged his path towards palliative care and helping patients integrate and understand their life in a meaningful way. BJ recounts several moving stories from his patients, which reveal important lessons about overcoming the fear of death, letting go of regret, and what’s most important in life. He discusses the major design flaws of a “death phobic” healthcare system. Furthermore, he makes the case that seeing death as a part of life allows us to live well, as opposed to living to evade death itself. He concludes with a discussion around physician-assisted death as well as his hopes around the use of psychedelics to reduce suffering in end-of-life care.

title: BJ's accident leading to the loss of his limbs and his experience inside a burn unit
content: Shortly after Thanksgiving in 1990, BJ was in college at Princeton at the time. He ended up losing both legs below the knee and his left arm below the elbow and spent months in the burn unit. A burn unit is a very different place that requires specialized doctors and nurses. Infection is very often the thing that kills people, hence all the sterility.

title: Coping with his amputations—being tough, the grieving process, and the healing properties of tears
content: When fasciotomies are performed initially, it’s with the hope of salvaging the limbs. They came to the realization trying to salvage the limbs was actually going to threaten BJ’s life due to infection. BJ had a memory of the conversation regarding amputation with the surgeon. BJ’s process of mourning the loss of his limbs.

title: BJ's Mourning Process
content: BJ's mourning process was delayed, and he was on autopilot in a way. It wasn't a thorough acceptance. A nurse urged BJ to let his real feelings out, and BJ began to cry, like a dam had been broken. The tears were a form of anesthesia. The underlying source of BJ's sadness and tears was a release of the physical pain, shame and embarrassment, and fear of going through life disabled.

title: How the Death of BJ's Sister Altered His Path
content: BJ had a sister who was 4 years older than him. Roughly 10 years after BJ’s accident, his sister committed suicide. At the time, BJ was in medical school and this event precipitated his decision to leave medicine.

title: How BJ Decided to Go into Medicine
content: While in recovery, BJ spent a lot of time pondering questions of meaning and identity. He was looking for meaning-making and this led to his fascination with art. He returned to Princeton and switched his major to art history. Peter's general advice for college students on what to study prior to med school is anything but pre-med. BJ agrees that people who study humanities then going into the healing professions are valuable.

title: BJ's new body liberated him
content: After his injuries, he almost felt more comfortable in his new body— “I got the body that much more mirrored how I felt inside; fragmented, broken, confused, unintegrated, different.” This mental process of accepting his new body, that it was the “right” body for him, really removed the sense of regret and second guessing he otherwise would’ve felt

title: How losing his sister to suicide and his disillusionment with medicine altered his path
content: His sister’s death led BJ to consider leaving medicine—he was demoralized that he was someone who wanted to heal people and yet he completely missed his sister’s diagnosis right under his nose

title: How BJ found his path in medicine
content: BJ has originally thought his path was going to be rehabilitation for people with traumatic injuries. But soon into his residency he realized he hated it. The whole idea of rehabilitation bothered him—It was so mechanical had nothing to do with the personal transformations. The goal was  to get people back to where they were before the injury. “I just don’t believe is true. It’s importantly untrue.”

title: Discovering his path of palliative care—distinct from hospice—in medicine
content: BJ thought he understood what hospice was—simply where people go for the final days of life. Then one day he stumbled into an elective called “palliative care” at the Medical College of Wisconsin. Dr. David Weissman was the oncologist there. On this day, BJ witnessed a conversation that was a transformative moment for him

title: Palliative Care
content: Palliative care is simply the interdisciplinary pursuit of the quality of life. Within the context of serious illness palliative care is that mode of care which helps you feel as well as possible—Emotionally, physically, spiritually. There is nothing in the definition of palliative care that makes it that you need be dying anytime soon—Death is included in this, but it’s not the focus. The thing that we treat in palliative care is suffering, not disease.

title: Hospice Care
content: Hospice is a subset of palliative care—it is essentially palliative care that’s applied at the end of life. That is a huge distinction — yet because many think palliative care and hospice are the same, nobody wants to talk about palliative care because of all the baggage around death. The consequence of conflating the two is that people suffer for years where they could get a lot more support through palliative care.

title: Our Complicated Relationship with Death
content: Even though all of us are going to die, it seems we don’t live like that is a reality. We are almost in denial, or just have an inability to look at death. BJ says it understandable and that we should cut ourselves some slack. We are wired to run away from death. We’re also the only species who is aware of our own eventual mortality. It’s quite a predicament we humans have, it’s a huge subject for us to wrap our heads around. A victim of our own success—due to advancing technologies and medicine, we’ve been able to extend lifespan and forestall death. So now that sense of urgency is lessened. Put all that stuff together and we’ve conspired to set up a pretty tricky relationship to this piece of our nature. People die much more miserable than they need to because they haven’t dared to look at this thing called death before it’s too late. Once you look at death and really accept it as a reality, two things happen: 1) You many realize it’s not so terrifying afterall 2) Once you come to terms with the fact that your time is limited and therefore precious, it has a secondary effect of helping you really, really appreciate what you have. The fact that it ends is what makes it precious. We don’t have to pick between maximizing our lifespan and accepting death.

title: Different types of fear of death
content:
Many of BJ’s patient present with a fear of death, but there’s an important distinction—
Are you afraid of the dying process?
Or are you afraid of being dead?
In the former, 
there are medications to help the body come down for a “gentle landing” (i.e., not suffer in physical pain)
So if that’s your fear, BJ offers his patients reassurance
If you fear is about being dead – what happens next, leaving your family behind, missing out, etc.
In this case, there is no clear “answer”
But “as a fellow traveler, I can accompany you there. We can think about that together. We can talk about it and then we can make a life that responds to that big question.”
Examples: 
If someone is worried about “judgement day”, then the solution is to help them behave differently in the time they have left
If someone’s fear is not living forever, “my favorite means to living forever is to think about the world beyond yourself; invest yourself in the world beyond yourself so when your self dies, that thing you love keeps going.”
“This is where it gets really, really fascinating, the relationship between self and other and what to do about that. Religious thinking, spiritual pursuits, this is what can open up when you admit that you’re freaked out to be dead.” —BJ Miller
Peter’s personal fear is around leaving his family behind, and missing out on the future generations
BJ’s point is that you CAN live through those things, but you have to make the investment, it doesn’t happen automatically
The irony is that you have to do it while you’re still alive and well, you can’t wait until your last moments
Palliative care should really begin much earlier in life
“It’s such a shame that we forestall and keep it at bay when it’s this thing that could help us so, so much.”
“Whether actually a palliative care referral or a palliative care mindset, but one way or another finding our way into this subject while we’ve got plenty of road in front of us, is absolutely the right, best way.”

title: The major design flaws of a “death phobic” healthcare system
content:
The overarching design flaw is that the system is focused on disease, not on the people dealing with disease
The second you make it about the person living with the disease, not the disease itself, you welcome in all sorts of things into the mix beyond just their physiology and anatomy:
Their social, emotional, and spiritual lives
You’ve welcomed your humanness into the mix as a clinician being relevant beyond just your technical skills
This can help with doctor burnout
It also helps with the expectation management—doctors can not be expected to work miracles: “We know that at some day everyone’s going to die and that that’s not a failure for us.”
“Once we align healthcare with the human condition and with serving human beings, so much of the trouble will work itself out.” —BJ Miller
Palliative care should be apart of everything
Given that 100% of patients die eventually, you’d think that palliative care would not need to be a specialty, it would be baked into how all of medicine works.
The healthcare system itself can’t keep doing what it’s doing and can’t keep death the enemy, because it’s going to lose that war again and again and again.

title: Design Flaws of Healthcare
content: We’re death phobic and we see ourselves as victors when we cure something. But chronic illness by definition is something that we can’t fix. Medicine is a series of transactions, which can work in acute care. But with chronic care, you’ve got to learn to live with it so illness and health becomes protracted over time. Therefore chronic care becomes an experience, yet we’re wired for transactions so we don’t have the systems and structures in place to be cultivating experiences together with our patients. Doctors are incentivized away from thinking about care over time.

title: Common Regrets of Hospice Patients
content: The common regrets of hospice patients include wishing they had spent more time with family that at work. But in most cases, the patient is dying from a chronic illness so they’ve had some protracted period of time to think about our death specifically. By the later stages of their life, their regrets show up more often in wishing as: I wish I had dared to love more. I wish I hadn’t been so afraid. I wish I had just let myself be myself. I wish I hadn’t been so hard on myself or criticized myself. The commonality is that they wish they had let themselves come to terms with death earlier in their lives, because it would have changed the decisions they made.

title: Addressing the Dying Wishes of Patients
content: BJ works with the Dream Foundation—an organization that helps make those wishes come true. Helping fulfill those wishes is SOME of BJ’s job, and when it’s practical to do so, “It’s fun. It’s great work. It’s powerful. It’s delightful and it’s stunning.” However, BJ finds himself more commonly helping patients see themselves in the world in such a way that they can let go of those things that they never got to, because they realize the things that they’re not going to get to is a very long list. “On a developmental level, you’ve got to find a way to come to terms with all the things you’re not going to get to do. That’s where I spend a lot of my time.”

title: Palliative care for Randy
content: Randy immediately moved into the Zen Hospice Project where BJ worked at the time where he played out the rest of his life. BJ had the sobering conversation with Randy that there was nothing that was going to help them at this point, except for love. In that conversation, BJ asked Randy, “what are you most proud of in yourself?” Without hesitation, Randy replied, “I want everybody I ever come into contact to know that I love them.”

title: Hastening death with physician-assisted dying: Legality and considerations
content: Physician-assisted dying (aka euthanasia) has been legalized in a handful of states (See list of states here). The process includes writing a letter for approval, there’s a 2 week wait, you have to have two physicians involved, etc. BJ says if hastening death was an option for Randy, he could imagine him taking that route given that the world was falling apart so quickly and it was just too painful mentally and physically for a little while there for Randy to “see straight”.

title: Psychedelics in end of life care
content: These same substances are being researched for anxieties around the fears of death in a patient population dealing with terminal illness or serious illness. BJ says the psilocybin data is the most exciting: People who are gripped by a fear of death, gripped by a sense of meaninglessness and not belonging and not feeling connected come out of one sessions losing their fear of death, feeling part of something larger than themselves, having a totally different relationship to fear. The effect lasts for a months suggesting it’s not just an acute chemical response. “We don’t have anything remotely like this to offer in medicine.” say BJ

title: BJ's view on death and suffering
content: BJ has nothing against those who choose to hasten death. For some people, it is exactly the right decision—but only when it is seen as a meaningful response, not a flight from suffering, but a moving towards something meaningful—And for some people that final act of will is very meaningful. But more often, what ends up being more meaningful for people is: Being more than their pain and suffering. Letting their body play itself all the way out and dealing with and adapting every moment along the way. And letting themselves grow right up until the moment of their death. “That’s actually a more meaningful pursuit for the bulk of people.”

title: BJ's excitement about moving beyond medicine
content: BJ is most excited about conversations, like this one with Peter, that are moving the conversation beyond just medicine. One of the great things that happens when we focus on the person is that people in the field of medicine can become part of something larger than ourselves. Physicians can partner with architects and artists, designers, and other disciplines. Or even death doulas and quasi medical folks and the alternative and integrative medicine folks. All of a sudden, we are part of a much larger family working on behalf of something much larger than even medicine.
